data.title: Local news in brief, 2/14
data.meta_description: Local and area news in brief
data.text:
By Staff Report

Man, chased by police, kills himself

A man wanted on a felony drug warrant fled from local police Thursday night and ultimately took his own life, San Angelo police said Saturday morning.

About 11:30 p.m., officers tried pull over a vehicle in the 4800 block of West Houston Harte Expressway for failing to stop at a red light, according to a police news release. The driver refused to stop.

The driver was later identified as Kevin Hasenbank, 35, and his passenger was identified as Michael Reisner, 25. Both men are of San Angelo.

Hasenbank abandoned his car in the north alleyway of the 3800 block of Sunset Boulevard and ran inside a residence, the release says. He then left the residence and hid behind a tree in a front yard.

According to the release, Hasenbank had a felony warrant for possession of a controlled substance and was in possession of a firearm.

Officers said Hasenbank said several times that he was unwilling to go to jail, according to the release. As police approached him, Hasenbank shot himself and died as a result of the self-inflicted wound.

Precinct 1 Justice of the Peace Jesse Martinez was called to the scene, as well as detectives from the police department's Criminal Investigations Division.

Reisner was released at the scene.

ASU names new development officer

Robert S. Clark has been named a development officer for Angelo State University, effective March 1.

Clark has served the past two years as special assistant to the senior associate athletic director for student-athlete development at Texas A&M University. In May, he will receive his Ph.D. in sport management from A&M.

Prior to joining Texas A&M, Clark worked as a college football recruiter for Occidental College, his alma mater, in Los Angeles. His related duties included assisting in special events and helping raise funds for the football team.

Clark holds a Bachelor of Arts in diplomacy and world affairs with a minor in education from Occidental College, where he also earned a Master of Arts in social science. Additionally, Clark had two years of marketing experience in the private sector with Dan Jones and Associates in Salt Lake City.

"I am very excited to serve Angelo State and the great people associated with ASU locally, regionally and throughout the great state of Texas," Clark said. "It's a great time for ASU athletics, and my family is excited to help advance the rich traditions of ASU."

Get sneak preview of kids' area at rodeo

The San Angelo Stock Show & Rodeo will offer a sneak peek of the Kids Korral at 3 p.m. Wednesday in the Qualtrust exhibit hall building, 50 E. 43rd St.

The exhibit will offer a first look at wildlife, reptiles and camels. A petting zoo also will be available.

For more information, call 325-653-9577.

ASU students attend national convention

Angelo State University's Center for Student Involvement is sending three students and two staff members to attend the National Association of Campus Activities Convention Saturday through Wednesday in Boston.

Rick Greig, director of student involvement, and Clint Havins, coordinator for student programs and activities, will accompany Sam Mendoza, graduate assistant for student programs and activities; Gary Stackhouse, University Center Program Council president; and Ty Mackey, UCPC entertainment chairman, to the convention. These five ASU representatives will attend educational sessions and performance showcases at the convention.

The NACA marks its 50th anniversary at the convention and will feature songwriter, producer and "American Idol" judge Kara DioGuardi as keynote speaker.

For more information on the ASU Center for Student Involvement, call 325-942-2062.

Monthly Art Walk coming Thursday

Downtown San Angelo will again play host to the Downtown Art Walk from 5 to 9 p.m. Thursday.

The featured art venue is the San Angelo Cultural Affairs Council, 212 S. Chadbourne St., featuring artist Liz Starnes,

The public can register Thursday for a drawing Thursday for two ticket packages: The first is for two tickets to the 26th annual Wine and Food Festival, and the second is for two tickets to the Fork and Cork tasting finale.

There will be a prayer service at J. Wilde's, 20 E. Concho Ave., at 6:15 p.m. Trolley service will be available for the walk.

For more information, call 325-653-4515 or 325-655-1234 or visit downtownsanangelo.com.

Christoval hosts Precinct 4 hopefuls

Tom Green County residents will have an opportunity to meet the candidates for Precinct 4 County Commissioner at 7 p.m. Thursday in the Christoval Community Center.

The candidates running in the Republican primary March 2 are Chad Buie, Yantis Green and Kenny McCrea. Johnny Silvas is running unopposed for the Democratic nomination for the seat.

The Christoval Community Chamber is sponsoring the event.

Republican Party dinner planned

The Tom Green County Republican Party will have its formal Lincoln Day Dinner at 6 p.m. Feb. 23 in the LeGrand Alumni Center, 1620 University Ave.

State Rep. Drew Darby and Texas Agriculture Commissioner Todd Staples will attend the event, which is co-hosted by the Concho Valley Republican Women's Club and the Angelo State University College Republicans.

For more information or ticket requests, call 325-486-2558.

AARP hosting driver safety class

The American Association of Retired Persons will have a driver safety class at 12:30 p.m. Feb. 24 at Trinity Lutheran Church, 3536 YMCA Drive.

The four-hour course is for individuals 50 years and older. It will provide instruction on age-related issues and how to adjust to them.

Cost is $12 for AARP members and $14 for nonmembers. A driver's license is required for registration.

For more information or to register, call 325-224-8363.

Club Cafe features acoustic guitarist

This month's Angelo State University Club Cafe will feature acoustic guitarist and singer/songwriter Hana Pestle at 7:30 p.m. Feb. 24 in the C.J. Davidson Conference Center, 1910 Rosemont Drive.

Pestle has recorded with writer and producer Michael "Fish" Herring and Evanescence co-founder Ben Moody and has recorded backup vocals for Celine Dion. In 2009, she released her first studio album, "This Way," and has opened for Collective Soul, Live and Blues Traveler.

Admission is $1 at the door, and refreshments will be served. For more information, call 325-942-2062 or visit angelo.edu/org/ucpc.

To sample Pestle's music, visit myspace.com/hanatunes.

Staff reports
